parameters: It's an aquarium with fish, snails, and shrimps.
Would you be \|interested in learning about fire shrimp?
Fire shrimp, genus Lysmata, are peaceful omnivores from the Indo-Pacifc region.
Our office's 200-gallon saltwater tank hosts two pairs of fire shrimp.
They are easy to spot from their deep red coloration and bright white appendages.
Do you help take care of the tank?
There was a maintenance guy who would come in when I first started here, but after admin realized I'd do it for free, he stopped showing up.
Is it a lot of work?
Once the tank is stable, it's not too bad. Feeding, cleaning the glass, emptying the skimmer cup...
Testing levels, changing out the water, checking the filter and lights, buying coral and rocks...
Fire shrimp are opportunistic scavengers. They'll eat pellets, brine, algae, vegetables.
I can even hand feed them a little bit of my lunch if I bust out the stepladder.
They are hermaphroditic. They act as males or females depending on where they are in the molting cycle.
We are fortunate to have such a large tank, and more fortunate still to have pairs who get along.
What about the other critters? The snails and the fish?
Originally, there were bigger fish, but they would attack the shrimp, so I disposed of them.
Admin insisted the tank "needed variety" and "couldn't be just shrimp," so I let a few fish and turbo snails stay.
Fire shrimp are quite shy by nature.
But you can tell they are happy if they are eating and active.
Do you keep a tank at your place too?
No. I spend more of my waking hours here than at home, so.
Yeah. I haven't felt like I should keep a pet for the same reason.
It's nice these ones can live here with you.
\|Is that not pet hair on your jacket?
Ha. God, it's everywhere, huh? It's from my roommates' cats.
They love me, but I don't get, y'know, kitty custody if we split ways.
Let me finish up. Can you wait a little longer?
It's an aquarium with fish, snails, and shrimps. Especially shrimps.
There's a Lee on the other side of this plexiglass.
That's where the pharm techs and I play phone tag.
And where the insurance reps and I play chicken, also known as peer-to-peer authorizations.
Magazines. The most recent cover date I see is 2002.
There's some decent quarterlies in there from a quarter decade ago.
Yeah. Famous early German Romantic painter.
This piece was found in his house after his untimely death.
The verso contained directions and instructions to have his body buried at the site of "Jade."
He passed just a few days after finishing this. The cause of death was pronounced a mystery.
The rumor goes the land was so hauntingly beautiful that it drove him to madness.
The later theory was that the area contained some parasite that lay dormant in his system for a few days and then killed him.
Like cordyceps infect its host and compel its ascent to sunlight, so "Jade" tempted Kopf into the earth that it could feed on his corpse.
Well, I was just paraphasing something I read online.
And, like, this was the 1800s. A lot of deaths were a mystery.
He almost definitely just killed himself. If you read his journal, he was psychotically depressed.
\|I am poor at detecting jokes. Are you messing with me?
No! No. It's Kopf. This is Art History 101.
I did think this was kind of a dark piece to put in a mental health waiting room, but whatever.
I just thought it was a calming scene.
And it is! You're not wrong.
Whatever the guy did after he made this shouldn't affect how you feel about it.
Yeah. Famous early German Romantic painter.

Would you be \|interested in learning about fire shrimp?
Fire shrimp, genus Lysmata, are peaceful omnivores from the Indo-Pacifc region.
Our office's 200-gallon saltwater tank hosts a healthy colony of over twenty fire shrimp.
They are easy to spot from their deep red coloration and bright white appendages.
Do you help take care of the tank?
There was a maintenance guy who would come in when I first started here, but after admin realized I'd do it for free, he stopped showing up.

Once the tank is stable, it's not too bad. Feeding, cleaning the glass, emptying the skimmer cup...

Fire shrimp are opportunistic scavengers. They'll eat anyting from algae to brine to pellets.
I like to give them a little bit of my lunch.
As you can see, they've taken to primarily occupying the aquarium's castle.
What about the other critters? The snails and the fish?
Originally, there were bigger fish, but they would eat the shrimp fry, so I disposed of them.
Admin insisted the tank "needed variety" and "couldn't be just shrimp," so I let a few fish and turbo snails stay.
Fire shrimp are quite shy by nature.
But you can tell they are happy if they're molting and breeding.
Do you keep a tank at your place too?
No. I spend more of my waking hours here than at home, so.
Yeah. I haven't felt like I should keep a pet for the same reason.
It's nice these ones can live here with you.
